Here is a problem from 1967, the so-called Six Day War.

There was a skirmish in the Sinai desert between:
142 Israelis
154 Egyptians 
69 oil wells were in the territory where the action took place
5 days was the length of the battle

Question:at the end of the skirmish who owned the oil wells?

Calculating:
142.15469x5 equals?
Turn your calculator upside down for the answer

Seeing STAYINALIVE took me back to my first job after college.  When Saturday Night Fever came out I was managing a luncheonette at Bryn Mawr college.  My co-worker was a passionate hater of disco, and found Saturday Night Fever especially irksome. The frequency with which students played STAYINALIVE on the jukebox eventually drove him to madness.  After four consecutive plays, he saw someone headed to the box for what he assumed was a fifth play, so he popped out from behind the counter, strode purposefully to the jukebox, yanked the plug out and announced that the jukebox was out of service. He stood there glaring and holding the plug daring anyone to contradict him.  The room fell into a stunned silence.  Satisfied, he returned to his place behind the counter and we finished out the lunch shift without further incident.  I like to think I‚Äôm pretty passionate about music, but I can‚Äôt hold a candle to my erstwhile colleague.

If IGA was a tricky one today, I warmly recommend learning her name as I suspect we'll see her for quite some time in these pages.

She's a tennis player, 23 years old, who's already spent over two years at the #1 ranking in the women's game and won five Grand Slam titles. She has a beautiful style of play and seems kind and gracious in interviews.

When you've got (imagine bold italics here) THREE (emphasis off now) Natick-y crossings to guess at, it just makes for a lot of boring work, not an enjoyable intellectual exercise.


I can see that there might be times when crossing proper names is acceptable, but it should be a last resort for constructors, discouraged by editors, and should only be allowed for ultra-mega-well-known famous names. (For instance, I'd be OK with Bob Hope crossing Bing Crosby at any "b" or "o").

07734.40 everybody! What a great puzzle, to fit all those themers in, cleverly clued, and do it symmetrically, and especially the Emily Bronte clue, that was simply fantastic. I'm sure that there will be complaints about MUKBANGS from those who need more Bang for their Muk, but none from me.  Everything worked out from the crosses. Agree that Liane could be Diane, but Luca sounds like a Pixar movie, Duca sounds a movie about Mussolini's daughter or perhaps found in an Italian diaper. Unless, of course, you're running a bat condo or a rat condo, in which case all bets are off.

You'll never impress anyone at a cocktail party with this, but just remember: Ellis Bell is Emily, Currer Bell is Charlotte: E-to-E; C-to-C.  No flies on those Bronte girls.  The real question is, could either Catherine Earnshaw or Isabella Linton be called bridezillas? Of the two, Catherine is the more socially ambitious and weirdly misguided, making more confounding decisions, like marrying Linton, so I guess she's got more zilla in her, although Isabella had an anger streak early on that went away with her shouldering more responsibilities.

Oh, just for an instant, when I saw the clues with the numbers, I thought of doing the math, but nah.  

Then I flashed on a brief scene from third grade, where someone showed me an upside-down calculator with the word meaning the opposite of heaven spelled in the display; my jaw dropped, and for a bit, it was the funniest and most amazing thing in the world.

I remember this scene clear as day even as I haven‚Äôt thought of it in many, many a decade.  Hah!  This memory thrust me right back into what it felt like to be me back then; it was like visiting a long-lost friend.  I started remembering other moments from elementary school, then home scenes with my family, even songs we sang around the piano.  For a brief interlude, tinged with pleasure and meaning, I was once again Little Me.

Thank you for that alone, Jacob, not to mention something else I realized while uncovering your fun puzzle, namely, that I have a talent ‚Äì the ability to read text upside down as comfortably as rightside up.  Maybe this comes naturally to everyone, but I never thought about it to the point of trying it out, until now. I picked out a book from the shelf, one by Zadie Smith, turned it upside down, started reading, and there was nary a hitch, even with words like ‚ÄúChurchillian‚Äù.  Hah again!

Yours was one of those puzzles, Jacob, where the gratification of cracking riddles was padded with ancillary pleasures, raising its enjoyment immeasurably.  Thank you!

As a cat owner, a cat condo sounds much more fashionable than the actual secondhand shag-rug-covered cat tree that my cats Maurice and Ginger kind of enjoy.

But @johnezra mentioned a RAT CONDO below and it brought to mind a slightly more squeamish story. I used to own a second home near the ocean and I was visiting there one week with a good friend. I went to walk on the beach and came back to find her in the fetal position in the corner. She pointed to a closet and I opened it to find THE BIGGEST DEAD RAT I HAVE EVER SEEN. 

As a traditional non-rodent loving woman, I shrieked like a schoolgirl and jumped up and down ... and soon realized that someone had to deal with this. 

I didn't think to call my property management company (it was my first year of ownership and I haven't started renting yet)... so I grabbed a pair of work gloves and grabbed him(her?) by the tail. Holding him/her as far as my arm would stretch (my friend still cowering in the corner), I walked slowly toward the deck, opened the slider, tiptoed to edge, and threw the rat (overhand) as far as humanly possible. Thank God he cleared the pool, fence, and trees and landed somewhere in the dunes.

For the rest of the time I owned that house we all referred to the incident as RATGATE...and I never again opened that closet without a racing heart and sweaty palms. 

Fortunately, it was an isolated incident and I was not actually running a RAT CONDO.

Happy Sunday!

Society has ingrained it into the brains of young girls that the wedding day is just THEIR special day, not even both the bride and the groom‚Äôs special day.  The bride is to be the center of attention, not the both of them. She buys a four-figure (or even five) gown, and dictates what her bridesmaids must wear; he and his groomsmen rent tuxes from Men‚Äôs Wearhouse. She boxes it up and keeps it forever; he sends them back with a chosen groomsman on Monday. 

If the groom is lucky, he gets to pick the style of tuxedo. The bride (and maybe her mother) picks everything else. Flowers, pictures, music, menu. 

Now the vast majority of young women handle this with grace and aplomb. But enough do not that it has become a stereotype. 

The number of men acting this way is infinitesimal because he never was the center of attention in the first place. 

All this, of course, presumes one bride and one groom. Other combinations may have different results. 

Stereotypes have a basis in reality. We just have to be careful not to paint everyone in a category with a broad brush. Very few brides are bridezillas.

Several days later, I opened the toilet lid to pee and there was a huge rat! I shrieked and put the lid down really fast and peed in the tub. 

What I haven't mentioned is that we were using flushable wheat cat litter that you were supposed to allow to break down for a few minutes in the toilet before flushing. That rat was having itself a yummy Wheaties snack.

Anyway, I flushed and lifted the lid again, and the rat was gone. But not for long. We kept a brick on the lid so the rat couldn't jump out while we waited a week for the landlord to do something about it. And we made a lot of noise every time we went in the bathroom to scare it away so it wouldn't show itself again. 

What took the landlord so long was that he didn't believe a rat could be living in the plumbing like that. But it turns out they can hold their breaths over 5 minutes and can come and go via the outlet pipe (or whatever it's called) on the roof. We knew when it had been there because it would leave behind fur and "pellets."

Finally, the landlord put a screen over that pipe on the roof, and the rat never came back.
